thread.title: Pepsi Returns to Bond Market to Repay Debt Before Fed Lift-Off
thread.title_full: Pepsi Returns to Bond Market to Repay Debt Before Fed Lift-Off - Bloomberg Business

author: Cordell Eddings
title: Pepsi Returns to Bond Market to Repay Debt Before Fed Lift-Off
text:
PepsiCo Inc. is tapping the bond market for a second time this year, joining a record rush of investment-grade borrowers looking to lock in near-record low borrowing costs before the Federal Reserve raises interest rates for the first time in nine years.
The world’s largest snack-maker may sell debt in as many as five parts, the longest portion of which will be due in 30 years and may yield 1.5 percentage points more than comparable government securities, according to a person with knowledge of the deal. The sale may take place Tuesday, the person said. Proceeds will be used to repay as much as $2.9 billion in short-term IOUs that Pepsi has outstanding and for general corporate purposes, the company said in a filing.
Pepsi, the world’s largest soft-drink maker after Coca-Cola Co., sold $2.5 billion in debt in April.
“We like Pepsi -- their leverage levels are strong, they have strong cash flows, and they’ve had strong performance this year,” said Jim Dunn, a New York-based analyst at researcher CreditSights Inc., said in a telephone interview Monday. “The deal should be well received.”
Pepsi has outperformed its peers so far this year, its shares rising 2.6 percent versus a 2.2 percent gain in the Standard & Poor’s Consumer Staples Index.
Forecast-Busting The company posted second-quarter profit last week that topped analysts’ estimates and boosted its forecast for the year, helped by cost cuts and rising snack sales in North America. Earnings in the three months through June 13 were $1.32 a share, excluding some items, the Purchase, New York-based company said in a statement.
Goldman Sachs Group Inc., HSBC Holdings Plc and JPMorgan Chase & Co. will arrange the debt sale, according to the filing.
Chief Executive Officer Indra Nooyi has worked to trim Pepsi’s expenses as the strong dollar damps sales abroad and Americans grow wary of soda over concerns about obesity and artificial sweeteners .
Investment-grade-rated companies have sold $739 billion in bonds so far this year, about 14 percent ahead of the pace set last year, which saw an unprecedented $1.097 trillion of the debt sold, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.
This has come as Fed policy makers debate raising their target rate this year from virtually zero, where they have held it since December 2008 to bolster economic growth. Fed Chair Janet Yellen may offer more insight into their plans when she begins two days of testimony before Congress on Wednesday.
